Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2011 01:05PM NJDevChick wrote: I hope you get some answers...I defnitely know how you feel...mins you can't "see" on the outside but it is very obviously there when you feel my breast.  I was told mine is "fat" because it isn't showing up on the Mammo or Ultrasound.  I just don't get how something THIS big doesn't show up.  What do they "think" it is?  Did they say it could be hardened fat?  I would definitely get a second opinion especially if you don't feel comfortable with the doctor's diagnosis.  Is there any way they can perform a biospy of the lump?  That is what I am going to push for....I keep thinking at 30 I am too young to have to worry about this!  But breast cancer occurs at my age, just more rare...
Posts.Title: Invisible Lump, apparently... FearlessSparkle KristenRank

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2011 12:12PM NJDevChick wrote: I am in a similiar position, only I have had the Ultrasound and Mammo, no MRI yet.  My lump isn't painful, but on occasion I will get a "shooting" pain in the area.  How big is your lump?  Does it feel hard or soft?  Smooth or bumpy?  Mine is oblong, Semi hard, although I it is pushing against a rib, so it is hard to really know how "hard" it is.  Mine was smooth up until a week or so ago and now it feels lumpy, but the lumps themselves are "smooth"  I am going to a breast surgeon in a week about another benign looking lump, but am definitely going to mention this.

Posts.Title: Quick Question for those that got Excisisional Biopsies NJDevChick 37antiques

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2011 08:23PM NJDevChick wrote: TRY not to get worked up too much.  About 2 weeks ago I found a large hard lump in the bottom of my left breast and was BESIDES myself in fear that I had advanced cancer.  Well it turned out to be a large hard lump of fat!  Who would have thought!  I didn't eat or sleep either and was a horrible mom and wife...well they did also find a tiny fibrodenoma that I can't even feel, but since my radiologist office doesn't do biopsy's, they are sending me to a breast surgeon to get it doubled checked.  Better to be TOO safe then sorry.  I am not worrying this time around as at our young age it is VERY VERY common to be a Fibro and if it is something then it is so tiny they caught it early.  I know staying calm is easier said then done, but I have been through it VERY recentely.  If you need someone to talk to feel free to private message me.  Lots of hugs and prayers going your way!  Everything will be fine!

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2011 02:10PM NJDevChick wrote: Thanks all...dye is injected...told him my concerns about it being attached to the muscle...he said it feels moveable (he's been doing this for 35 yrs) and sometimes scar tissue can attach to muscle too and my "lesion" could be attached to that...he is leaning towards benign but he said that is why we are taking it out and doing a biopsy so we know exactly what we are dealing with.  He also said because of the size it is good to have it out and you could take samples of a large mass and miss spots that actually have cancer in them....he said regardless it is coming out completely...so that is reassuring.  I said do benign conditions end up cancer...he said yes but also cancerious masses turn out benign, that is why we do the biopsy...

Posts.Content: NJDevChick wrote: Hi guys, Haven't been on in a couple of weeks...trying to be normal after radiologist told me my large mass was fat (necrosis) I believe, but I am still worried they were wrong.  What are the chances?  Sometimes I swear my breast goes in on the one side after pushing on the spot for awhile, but it returns to it's normal position if I watch it for a minute or so...I am so scared that it is a "dimple" in my breast and the radiologist was wrong.  I am going to a breast surgeon on May 3rd for another small fibrodenoma that they want double checked, but I am driving myself crazy in the meantime.  I have shoulder pain that isn't going away and on occasion I get a small shooting pain in the area of the "mass" although when I am sitting up and feeling it, the lump is very movable and is smooth in appearence.  Has anyone else had experience with hard lumps of fat in the breast?  I am driving my husband crazy thinking that I have cancer that has spread to the shoulder and that my OBGYN, and the radiologist who performed a diagnostic mammogram and ultrasound were both wrong....the mass is when laying back starts at the very bottom of my breast pretty much against the rib, but I am small chested, the mass feels like it is very close to the surface of the skin when laying back because my breast basicaly go flat when laying back.  I am so concerned that they were wrong and I have something bad going on...my husband has been very understanding for the longest time, but I am a bad worrier and he even told me "when the test shows up OK, we need to be done with this" and I haven't been, after being OK for 2 weeks, I am slipping back into a depressive state....sorry for the ramble... Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2011 02:56PM NJDevChick wrote: babre, you are absolutely right.  I am just an irrational person, it seems like when I turned 30 last year I started to have a lot of anxiety, more than "normal" for me.  I also got laid off around my birthday last year as well so I have ALL THE TIME in the world to think.  I stopped drinking coffee about a month ago and it seemed to ease that "shooting" pain in the breast, and I do wear an underwire, and I am a runner so I don't know if that constantly pushing at that area could have caused it either... I just can't believe they just think it is a fatty lump.  Also, I just picked up my report and the radiologist classified my fibrodenoma (the smaller lump) as BI-RADS 3, saying it was the choice if my breast surgeon wanted to remove it (its 1 cm X 0.6 X 1.5 so it is small, so if they don't remove it they want to check it again in 4-6 months to make sure nothing has changed.  I probably have caused half the pains I have been feeling by all the pocking and prodding I do on top of the stress I feel, why can't I just let things go, I wish I was carefree lol!   carpe-I am going to ask the breast surgeon next month about that...I feel I will never be able to "fully " let it go unless it disappears or is removed.  I do feel though that it wouldn't be "that" free moving if it was truly something, and it definitely doesn't feel "as hard" when I push it sitting up rather than laying back and it pushing against my rib cage.
